name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Law and Order

transcript.content: Aristotle once observed, law is order and good law is good order. A seemingly simple concept, but the realities of making those good laws and enforcing them have troubled society since time immemorial. From community service to capital punishment, everyone has a view on how we protect the innocent and punish the guilty. Is one man's law another man's tyranny? Is justice available to all? Does prison work? Should we lock up law breakers and throw away the key? Or does that fail to address the root causes of crime? To discuss these questions and more, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
And Karl Pilkington. Look at that fucking head.
I'm not that interested in it to be honest.
I've got no interest in law and order whatsoever. It's not part of my life. That's the problem. You keep picking topics that don't buzz me.
Well, let's talk about this. Let's talk about this.
You're a man quite obsessed with law and order.

Well, law and order is basically to protect the innocent, isn't it? I mean, when we think of law and order, we usually think of crime and punishment, but it's all about protect our person. We have the right to walk the streets without getting mugged when someone wrongs us. We want justice. It's fundamental. And you do. You were sitting in your old flat in London in front of me every day that you wanted to go downstairs and smack their heads in for being late and shouting around and being drunk, and you could hear it. You wanted some justice.
Yeah, but nothing would have happened if I called someone up and said, there's people doing noise pollution, even though there's a law for noise pollution now, it's not really taken seriously, is it?
But you are concerned with law and order.
You wanted your rights. And you ended up moving. He's moved here now. He's moved to lovely sunny Hampstead, just down the road from us. So you're having a better life.
I shouldn't have to move because of some noisy people?
No, you shouldn't, but I'm saying you were stressed-
-and you wanted justice, but you thought you couldn't get justice, so you moved away which is-
So I dealt with it in my way.
I hated them because they didn't care about anyone else.
The police wouldn't get involved. There's other people who live around there who had to put up with it. No one cared.
So what did it feel like every night when you were trying to watch telly and it's hot and you got the window open? All yeah.

You could just hear stuff it's that thing of you get a lot of tourists in London, so they talk. And it's not even as if you can listen into what they say and have a view on their opinion, because they're foreign.
Would that be entertaining for you.
Well, yeah, because if you can hear what people are saying. You're going "Oh yeah that's a good point"
"Switch the tele off" [laughing] that's a good point?
I don't want to hear anyone talking.

I'll tell you what, I really feel sorry for people with like, neighbours from hell because I'm not saying it's just fine, but I can see why people go mental with someone when they're bullied or constantly harassed and no one cares. And when you can't go to the police, you can't go to police and go "there's a bloke next door, he's got his tele on too loud. He's always pissed. He's shouting about. If you don't do something, I'm going to go around there and crack his head in. You'd be the one that...

Yeah. Just to get out your system, when you know you've been conned, you just laugh in the face of adversity. I remember, um, it was, um, a couple of days before Christmas. I was going away, but I had a dripping tap and it started dripping more, so, uh, there was nothing I could do. The maintenance people were away, the caretaker's away, I couldn't get in a--. So, I uh, I called out an emergency plumber. I knew this was going to cost, but bloke came round. Honestly, he made you look smart. He was like one of those kids who looked like a lumpy child. He was probably 20-
--but he just looked like - you know what I mean? -
--they'd scaled up a sort of 13 year old big faced lad.

Right? He went "Alright?" And he came in and uh, he didn't know how to stop it. He couldn't unscrew it. He went, "I don't know what to do." I called my brother, he's there just- I said, "Uh, Bob, what can I do?" He said, "You could crush the pipe and then get it cut and fixed when you got..." I said, "Great idea." So I said to the plumber, I said, "Can we crush the pipe?" "Oh, yeah, I'll go and get a tool." He went down the van, came up with this thing, like a fat sort of little pair of pliers. He couldn't- he wasn't strong enough, so I went, [Sighs] I had a go. I said, "How about we both do it?" So we both put our hands on it and we managed to crush the pipe, flatten the pipe, cut it off. He put a little thing on the end of it so it wouldn't leak, eh? I went, "Great." Uh, I said, uh, "How much is that?" He went "180 quid." So I went, "Right, okay." So I wrote him out a cheque for 180 quid and I thought I'll have a bit of sarcasm. So it wasn't his idea, I helped him do it. I went, "How much was that tool?" He went, "[Sighs] About a fiver." I went, "That's paid for itself innit?"
Silence - he went, "Yep." Just nothing. Just nothing. Tough crowd. Right?
So I signed the cheque, and he went, "[Sighs]" he said, "I forgot to charge you for the little washer on the end." I went, "How much is that?" He went, "£2.50." I went, "Can I give you that in cash?"

"I written--" He went "Yeah." I went, "There you go, there's- there's the £2.50 for the washer on the end and there's the £180." And he went and that was it. I didn't even get a little chuckle. He didn't even think... He should've gone, "Well, let's split that because we both did that."
"Yeah, that's 90 quid each." I go, "Okay, yeah, that's brilliant mate. Cheers. Here's a Christmas bonus."

I have, uh, a fascinating tale to tell you, Karl. I think you'll be intrigued. Um, when I do, um, junkets for films in, in, America or, uh, Toronto Film Festival, um I was assigned a security. And uh, I've had security before, often have security, they just sort of get you in and out of the car and- usually just to control sort of autograph hunters and things and... But um, this time I was given a security and he came in a suit. He was about 30, he looked quite unassuming. I thought he was from a, just a security firm and there was a couple of them and uh, first of all, they were talking to each other and I thought, "Well, the stakes are higher here, I don't know why." And uh, they drove us to the hotel and there was  uh, loads of people going into the hotel. I mean, much bigger stars than me, you know? There was Ed Norton and- and George Clooney and they were going in and out. And he goes, "I- we can go past these." And he called ahead and he knew everyone, he just knew everyone. And we went down in the car park. We were met by another security guard in the hotel that let us go past everyone. I mean, Clooney's having to queue up and sign. I'm thinking, "This is weird." And I was feeling bit guilty because I was there to promote the film and I think, "This security guard is so good, I'm never going to ever have to bump into anyone." It was amazing.

And he were there the next day and he took us to the junket and back and he put us on the thing and then it turned out that, uh, he was actually LAPD, who was doing this for celebrities 'cause he earned more money. And then um, I found out I had a gun. He said, "I can't come in the airport with you, I can't take my gun." So... he's armed. So I've got a security who's LAPD, who's- who's armed. And I'm fascinated now, I'm fascinated. This man is walking around with me with a little earpiece, talking to everyone, he seems to know everyone, and he's got a gun. I think, "This is amazing." Then one night he said, uh, he dropped me off at the hotel and he said, "Uh, I've actually been called. I've got to go on a mission. They need my help." I said, "What is it?" He said, "It's a hostage situation," he said, "And I'm, I'm also SWAT." So now I'm just- this is amazing. He's now officially the coolest man I've ever met in my life. So he goes off. Then I'm thinking and I'm worried about him. And I was talking to Jane, I was thinking, "Wow, he does this to get some extra cash, he's risking his life, and now he's going to a hostage situation." And I was thinking, "Oh God, it's just- he's just a silent hero."
So next day he comes up, I said, "How was it?" He said, "Oh it was fine," he said, "I just turned up," he said, "I had to- I had to do it in my suit," he said, uh, "'cause I'm the negotiator."

synopsis.description: Karl has no opinion on Law and Order.
